title: Improved Logitech Webcam to Microscope Adapter

description.text:
A redesign to accommodate taller eyepieces such as the inexpensive AmScope 10X WF. The tube and camera holder are printed separately to avoid using support material. The two pieces are glued together with superglue.
This fits the Logitech Quickcam Pro for Notebooks and other models that use the same case, and B&L Balplan microscope with 31.1mm dia eyepiece tube.
Video shot using this adapter here: https://vimeo.com/83166718

Printed with Octave black ABS, 0.35 mm nozzle, 0.35mm first layer, 0.2 mm layers for all others. 20% infill, no support material.
After gluing be sure to let the glue harden completely before putting the adapter on your camera or microscope- superglue vapors are very good for rendering fingerprints visible! When you glue, carefully align the edge of the tube with the edge of the camera holder.
Video shot using this adapter can be seen here:
https://vimeo.com/83192683
https://vimeo.com/83166718

description.text:
Make your large build plate level with this wedge jack!

With my CR10-S4 I found out that the large 400x400mm build plate was sagging noticeably in the middle. While there are adjustment screws on the four corners there is no way to support the middle of the build plate; this is what this part is for. Once assembled you can slide this in between your build plate and the lower support/mounting plate. Create support for the middle of the build plate and raise it using this W-Jack until level with the four corners by turning the screw. Note that this part is designed to be used in conjunction with a 3mm cork pad between it and the hot print bed.

Tip#1 Don't place the wedgejack directly under the temperature sensor on your heated bed otherwise you might damage it.

Tip#2 Use a long (7" or more), fine screw driver to easily reach the wedge jack from the edge of the plate when adjusting it.

Bonus Tip: This device is designed to have 4 mm of overall vertical travel controlled by 20 mm of horizontal movement, giving you very fine control when leveling the sag out of the build plate. With the screw I used it works out to about 0.285 mm of vertical travel for each full turn of the screw.

comments.author: bshady3

comments.text:
I'll try my best to describe this. The jack is composed of three parts being 1) the upper wedge 2) the lower wedge 3) the frame. The lower wedge has the nut in it. The screw goes through the hole in the frame and screws into the nut that is in the lower wedge. When you turn the screw tighter it pulls the lower wedge towards that side of the frame.
Now when you add the upper wedge on top of the lower wedge, like in the pictures, you get the lifting action. As the lower wedge is pulled by the screw it forces the upper wedge up. The upper wedge is caught in the frame so up is the only way it can go when the lower wedge pushes into it.
I hope that explains it.

remixed_from.title: Bearing Spool Holder for UP! pp3dp

description.text:
This is an adaptation for Lulzbot Taz 6. The Lulzbot uses an arm with a 8x16 rectangular profile as a spool holder. I just took the existing spool bearing "thing" and changed the center hole to a rectangle to fit the above, also added a small U shaped piece to keep the spool and bearing in place with no sliding across the Lulzbot arm.

Works great for me. I printed in ABS and nGen and the nGen version came out better (this material prints slower and it works well for spheres). You need to use supports, but those pieces require almost no cleanup after you take the supports out. The type of supports I used are the build in Cura default.

Use the orientation on the files: the bearing with the wider part flat on the bed, and the "U" bar vertically when printing.

comments.text: I made on of these on my TAX 6 using PolyLite and the default settings for that material, with "supports" enabled.  The ball bearings did not print well, The supports seemed to turn into fuzzballs.  Everything else was fine.  The ball bearings, while they do not "roll" much still allow the bearing overall to turn adequately after clearing out as much of the support material as possible.

title: LG Nexus 5X w slim case camera screw mount

description.text:
This mount will hold a LG Nexus 5X with a slim case. This means that this will not work with a bare 5X (without a slim case).

The mount hole is threaded with 3/8-16, so an adapter screw will be very easy to fit.

There is a "cut out" to be able to fit a usb charging cable.

The "washer" stl is to be fitted under the mount to fill out for an adapter screw that is longer than what the mount is thick (fit between the actually camera screw support plate and this mount).

Hardware needed:
1/4 => 3/8 screw adapter like the one in one of the attach pictures.

Of course you need some hardware to attach the mount to. There is a lot of options for this. Tripods, bicycle mounts, GoPro mounts and other standard camera mounts. I use the mount to attach my S5 to my MC.

title: MYSensors temperature humidity sensor
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Box for mysensors temperature and humidity sensor. The box holds the pcb board and a battery holder for 2 AA-batteries.

For download I added:

  • stl-files fort printing the box
  • picture of the pcb-board
  • schematics of the pcb front and back
  • circuit diagram of the pcb
  • software for the processor (ATmega328)

To complete the pcd you need additionally: Atmega328, RFM69HCW, Si7021 or other temperature/humidity node. The software is capable for Si7021, but I also developped one for DHT22. In case you don't want to manufacture the pcb on your own, or have any problems in sourcing RFM69 or Si7021, please let me know. I'm always happy to help.

Very low power consumption!!! Mine is running since 6 months using 2 AA-NiMH batteries, which are still at 1.2V each. It's at <10 microAmp.

Theo pcb is designed very generic, so that it allows also to add a lot of other sensors or circuits. For this thing you just need to solder the Atmega328, RFM69, Si7021(=IC3), C1 (100nF), R1 and R2 (4.7k). Additionally you need to close SJ1.

For more information please see also:
https://www.openhardware.io/view/354/MySensor-RFM69HCW-micro-pcb-for-DHT-Si7021-CNY70

print_settings.Notes:: It's far easier printing smaller pieces and glue'ing it together. That's why i have halves of the upper and lower part of the lockers.

description.text:
This is the first part of a "Järvsöskåp" a swedish lockers derived from a county called Hälsingland in Sweden. These lockers got a long history in sweden and some of these lockers can be hundreds of years old!

This is the lower part of the lockers. I have yet to finish the upperpart or the door to the lower part since im exhausted after a 15 hour nonstop run making the lowerpart. I'm satisfied with the result.

I might do some more "polishing" on it later.

This is the first 3d print i have spent a devoted time on. Still learning. Still going strong.

EDIT: I added the door, a lock mechanism and a key 2017-03-12(year-month-day).

EDIT: I remodeled the door, made it bigger, i made the lock seperate and bigger. So glue is required. Bigger hinges for glueing. New key. 2017-03-13

**EDIT: I remodeled the door once again. I kept the original size but i made the hinges seperate and bigger, i also added small glue slots at the side of the door in which where to attach the hinges.
I also focused on simply making holes in the doors, where a piece of a metalclip have to suffice as a lock mechanism since it was a nuisance trying to design locks.
The upperpart is finished :D!

To the upperpart there is 2 boxes and hinges that needs to be glued to the door and the lockers. 2017-03-30(Year-Month-Day). **

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Finder

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Standard

Infill:

15%.

Notes:

It's far easier printing smaller pieces and glue'ing it together. That's why i have halves of the upper and lower part of the lockers.

I used mirroring to make only half the work.

I like the mirror function, so i just do half the measurement originally and design a "half". Then i just copy it and mirror it, and group it together.

I watched pictures from my own real life scale of a lockers residing in the dinning room.
The lockers scale is 1:9.

I got tons of saved files of the small parts i used to make the corners, frames and embodiments if someone is interested. :)

title: RunCam Swift dampened mount for S500 Quadcopter

description.text: A quick sketch done in Tinkercad for mounting a RunCam Swift (Owl Plus might also work) to the Hobbyking S500 Quadcopter Frame using cheap rubber dampeners that can be bought from ebay (search for: "Vibration Dampening Rubber Balls"). The dampeners can be directly attached to the front of the frame's PCB and help to reduce small vibrations induced by the motors and props.

title: Hydrogen Reactor v.1.00
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This desktop model is designed for fun or classroom demonstration. The reactor separates hydrogen and oxygen from salt water via electrolysis using a 9V battery. The gases are collected at the top of the reactor. The gases can then be used to fill a balloon or create a loud pop if exposed to flame.   
This project is a work in progress. If you have any suggestions for improvement, please let me know. Good luck and happy science!  
DISCLAIMER: I do not accept any responsibility for injury or damage as a result of using this item. Gaseous hydrogen, when mixed with oxygen, is very combustable. Additionally, the wastewater produced by the item may be toxic. Be safe!

The reactor was designed for use with ReplicatorG.
Recommended Settings:
100% infill
1 shell
Exterior Support
All Others Default
Print the four parts but do not print the entire assembly,(Reactor_Assembly.stl). It would not function. Afterwards, follow theses steps to get the reactor up and running. 1.) Place a 9V household battery in the slot inside the reactor base. 2.) Connect the Toxic Waste Collector to the tube extending from the reactor base. You may glue in it place to seal any holes if you choose. 3.) Slide the Floodgate into the slot in the Toxic Waste Collector. The floodgate prevents water from escaping the reactor. 4.) Fill the reactor with saltwater. The water can be from tap, mixed with a couple spoonfuls of salt. At this point, bubbles will rapidly rise from the battery terminals. 5.) Connect the gas collector to the top of the reactor. You may choose to fill the remaining empty space in the gas collector with salt water. Be careful though, as water may spill out during this step. 6.) Cover the top of the gas collector with clear cellophane or tape. Slowly but surely, bubbles will collect. It takes about an hour or two to get a useful amount of gas. That's it! If you run low on saltwater, simply add more via the small hole on the side of the gas collector. When you are finished with the reactor, the waste water should be disposed. It may appear brown, or green, depending on the battery and water used. The waste water is toxic, and may contain traces of battery acid. Proper safety equipment is a must.

title: Extended high flow  fan duct for Anet A8 with autolevel sensor

description.text:
This is version 2: The distnce to the nozzle has been reduced and the airlow in direction to the nozzle was reduced.

This is a duct optimized to maximize the air flow and to compensate the additional diatance between fan and nozzle due to this autolevel sensor support:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1911146

Without this sensor support the duct might colide with the nozzle.

The design is kept basic and simple and is easy to print. No support is needed and the overhangs are limited to 45°. The flat area at the bottom is ment to be the basis when printing. A 2.5mm hole is added to cut a M3 theread for a small bolt keep it in place.

The cross section area is conciderably larger than the original stock duct.

Due to the high temperature near the nozzle best printed in ABS.

author: kaefigtier

description.text: Front bezel for 4 x 20 characters LCD

UPDATED 3/17/17 Changed the bracket mount angle, made it 3mm thick, added supports at each end.
UPDATED 3/12/17 If you downloaded earlier may want to again...

I never liked the power switches for the InMoov located in the back covers where you have to disconnect everything to get the back off. Usually the reason the back is off is because I'm messing about with the electronics in there and need the power all wired up. Now the switches are at the back of the neck, and one easy swipe kills it all. (or just my first switch gives power to the others - so it's a kill switch)

I drilled a couple small holes at the top of the faceplate to hold it in place, so removal allows threading of wires up into the skull. I used these rocker switches from Amazon: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B008X10YRC/ref=oh_aui_search_detailpage?ie=UTF8&psc=1

I also created two plugs (L and R) for the resulting holes in the back covers where the switches once were.

title: Filtro mini interno para acuario / aquarium mini filter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Es un filtro interno de pequeño tamaño, diseñado para ser usado en acuarios de tamaño reducido. Yo lo utilizo para un acuario enfermería. Utiliza una pequeña bomba comercial para acuarios de 300 l/h. El tubo de salida está unido a la bomba por medio de un pequeño trozo de tubo de PVC, lo que le proporciona una unión flexible que facilita el montaje. Tanto en el cesto como sobre la rejilla se puede colocar cualquier combinación de filtros que se desee (perlón, esponja, canutillos cerámicos, carbón activado, etc.).
El agua es aspirada por la parte superior del cuerpo del filtro y es expulsada por la boquilla superior. El tubo de salida es telescópico lo que permite ajustar la altura de la boquilla a la altura deseada y orientarla en cualquier dirección.
Las medidas del filtro son:
Cuerpo del filtro: 10x6x6 cm.
Altura mínima de la boquilla de salida: 15 cm. (medida desde la base del filtro).
Altura máxima de la boquilla de salida: 19 cm. (medida desde la base del filtro).

description.text: This is a Protection for the hotbed of the Anet A8 or other printers with the Anet A8 hotbed. The springs sometimes caused issues and damaged the hotbeds bottom layer. There have been cases were the hotbed even sparked and caught fire! This fixes the issue, but be carefull! If you print this with PLA it can melt if the hotbed is to hot.

Ready to assemble Dell SFF Drive tray.

Everything was printed with 20% infill with basic settings using PLA. Modeled from the ground up using a Dell OEM drive tray.

The handle is plenty strong and allows you to pull the drive in and out easily. One rail does have a cut out so the drive can slide all the way into the back plane. All you need are 4 screws just about any should work. The handle/connector is a tight fit into the two side rails which give it some extra strength.

I had some of these laying around from a different project: http://www.ebay.com/itm/-/180999268972

comments.text: Just got my R710 today from Fedex, so glad i found this, saves me money from having to spend that extra on drives bays. yay!!!

title: Rostock Max V2 Side Panel Venting
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The stock cooling fan for the lower base on the Rostock Max V2 is pretty noisy. I think part of that is related to the grid pattern in the side panel that it is mounted on. I picked up quieter, larger 80mm fans and designed what I hope is a higher flow, quieter shroud that works with a replacement panel for mounting on the side of the printer.

I also wanted to have some fun with the potential to have even quieter exhaust while still maintaining good air flow. I saw another design that modeled a jet engine shroud and I recalled how some of the newer engines have a very cool looking sawtooth pattern. I doubt this shroud design will contribute to quieter performance more than just running a quieter fan, but I think it looks cool.

I've also included a shroud to mount directly on an 80mm fan.

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX v2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm layer with .4 nozzle

Infill:

20% hexagonal

Notes:

I printed these with Microcenter Inland ABS on a glass bed with glue stick. I do have an enclosure on my printer which makes printing large flat parts out of ABS possible. I also added anchor dots to the panels to be absolutely sure they stayed put as I printed.

Shroud panel assembly

Since the shroud and panel were being joined together at the base layers, I just brushed on some acetone and held them together for a few seconds.

remixed_from.author: tezz
remixed_from.title: Delta Kossel 15mm Magnetic Carriage with Belt Tensioner

description.text:
This is my WIP Kossel effector for magnetic arms with ball-studs and an E3D v6. It also features a Y-joint built into the effector mounting bracket to allow for single nozzle dual extrusion.

Note that while the preview screenshot contains a fan, I haven't finished that mount yet.

Here's the gcode I use for tool change in Simplify 3d:

;BEGIN TOOL CHANGE
G92 E0
G1 E-9 F[toolchange_retract_speed] ; retract previous tool
G91
G1 Z5 F[travel_speed] ; lift
G90
G1 E-40 F300
G1 E-[toolchange_retract_distance] F[toolchange_retract_speed]
T[new_tool] ; switch to new tool and offsets
G1 X[next_position_x] Y[next_position_y] F[travel_speed] ; move to next printing location
G92 E0
G1 E[toolchange_prime_distance] F1800 ; prime new tool
G92 E0
G1 Z[next_position_z] F[travel_speed]
;END TOOL CHANGE

Note that this absolutely requires a priming tower.
The key insight in the gcode is to do a normal retraction, a slow retraction to let the filament cool rather than making a long tail, then a long and fast retraction to get it all the way up the Y-joint. It's a balance - if you retract too quickly, you get a long tail on the filament and jam. If you retract too slowly, you get blobs.

In this case, my retraction distance is 8mm, my retraction speed is 40mm/sec, my toolchange retraction distance is 90mm, and my toolchange retraction speed is 50mm/sec.

UPDATED! Heat and a poor design led to my bracket breaking & folding open. Version 2 has a better backbone.OEM clips only need 3 even with this upgrade I'll probably print 4 to spread out the weight.
Two of the clips that hold the piece of vinyl that hides the track for my vertical blinds broke. So out came the calipers!

Someone from the NoVA hackerspace community took pity and printed this for me. His tips:
  • On a Mosaic - might have to move a clip or two as its extents are within 20mm from the edge
  • 100% infill(single shell would be better (that one is 30% 3 shell)
  • 0.25 layer height.
    • It clips right on. The attached image shows the original with some rough scale. I'll try to get some more of the new one with the original and in action

description.text:
This is a miniature strap wrench that uses a GT2 belt. It is useful for small parts that can't be gripped by a regular strap wrench. It could also be used in the shop or kitchen for small bottle (or tube) caps.

I made this because I needed a tool to rotate a soft plastic part that I couldn't risk marring. The truth is I didn't have time to design and print the wrench so I worked around the problem; but next time I'll be ready!

You'll need a length of GT2 belt to make this. I used about 30 cm.

title: Marker Stand, various sizes (Fits Posca, Molotow, Promarker, Copic, Sta...)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
If you want to hold paintbrushes or colored pencils, I recommend the Cubistand from sdmc : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1294085 I use it for my brushes and it was a great inspiration for me.

Here is 3 different marker stands, for (mostly) any size of markers. If you own markers that does not fit well with any of my stands, feel free to give me the dimensions of your markers in the comment section, I will make a new stand for yours. I will upgrade the MarkerStands depending of my needs.

MarkerStand 13mm - for 44 markers
(Fits Posca (PC1M, PC1MR), Molotow (One4All Twin, 127HS)...)
MarkerStand 17mm - for 44 markers
(Fits Posca (PC1M), Copic Markers, ProMarkers)
MarkerStand 19mm - for 27 markers
(Fits Posca (PC5M), Molotow (One4All 227HS, 327HS)...)
MarkerStand 28mm - for 12 markers
(Fits Posca (PC8K, PC18K), Molotow (440PP, 626HS)...)

Presentation video : https://youtu.be/D2dxbqDuxKo

Printer:

prusa i3, CoreXY, Tarantula

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

6%

Notes:

Nothing fancy :

  • it is printed reasonably fast
  • better with 0.5, 0.3, 0.25mm nozzles
  • bottom 2 layers ; top 4 layers

Design talk...

As an early user of the Cubistand for my brushes, I enjoyed a lot the concept. I tryed to print an enlarged version for my markers, but the Cubistand was not good for markers because they're mostly of the same size unlike the brushes. So it's hard to peak up a marker in the middle of the stand. Otherhand, scaled up, the cubistand was too high for smaller markers. I realy needed to work on a new concept.

As ex-POS professionnal, I know accessibility of the product is crucial for any user experience with a display. There's many ways to display items of the same size with ease of use. But this is a desktop stand, it's meant to be compact, especially because designers often own hundreds of markers. I tried some compact display forms, different measurements, and I ended with a stepped display that combines a very small foot print, not much printing material, and a pretty easy access to the markers.

Feel free to write a comment if you've got any improvement idea about it.

A bespoke replacement part for a friend's oven. The original was in a white thermosetting resin and one of a pair had broken, so I used the remaining piece to make a new pair for the oven handles.

title: Even more minimal MK7 extruder bearing filament feeder

description.text: This is a slightly modified version of whosawhatsis' original minimal version. I didn't have the right spring, and the original one seemed to be set up more for 3mm filament. So I borrowed TopperDEL's idea of using a machine screw to create the necessary compression. So this version does not have the quick change feature, but now only needs the 623 bearing and standard M3 screws.

• Print parts. I did mine at 50% infill for strength.

  • Remove the little support cylinder so the bearing can fit in the slot and use a long M3 screw to secure the bearing threading it from "underneath", i.e. from the side that will face the stepper motor. Thread the screw until it is flush with the top surface. Use some heavy duty wire cutters to clip the screw as flush as possible. It's OK if the screw protrudes slightly on the side that faces the motor.

  • Attach the parts to the stepper motor using the original flush mount screws and reassemble the other components.

  • Thread a long M3 screw through the hole in the pivot arm, and with some 1.75 mm filament in place, tighten the screw until the motor can feed it properly without slipping.
    • I've found that once the tension is set properly, it's really easy to thread new filament and I no longer have problems with misfeeds etc. I've never tried changing filament mid-print, so I have no idea if that can be done with this setup!

comments.text: Word of warning don't over tighten. I did and i thought my nozzle was clogged but later found out after disassembling it for gear cleaning that it was impossible to turn. If you have a flat on your extruder motor shaft try to turn it by hand when the motor is off.
comments.author: laughingman

comments.text: Fantastic design!  Prints beautifully! I was having issues with the filament tension of the mk7 and they have all been resolved with this! I even printed a few of prettysmallthings' chairs which were just moosh before!
comments.author: ClimbingStuff

comments.text: Thanks for the nice words, but the credit really all belongs to whosawhatsis  (and TopperDEL) who did the hard part! I just tweaked it very slightly!
comments.author: ClimbingStuff

comments.text: Just curious. The MK7 Extruder from Makerbot uses a Nema 17 or 23 stepper motor? Looks like it's a Nema 23.
comments.author: freakinhuge

comments.text: Nevermind I found it on the spec page. http://store.makerbot.com/stepstruder-mk7-complete.htmlhttp://store.makerbot.com/step...
comments.author: freakinhuge

comments.text: I guess it's a 44oz one?
comments.author: freakinhuge

comments.text: Hi, curious how your performance has been. Your motor looks a bit small for a direct drive extruder. I'm speaking from experience, I've been using the one designed by whosawhatsis and a motor that looks exactly like yours. I bought a pack of them off ebay. Recently had to upgrade to a larger motor because it was having problems.
comments.author: brianblanton

comments.text: It's been flawless so far. The motor is the stock MK7 stepper (moon stepper?) and it's been plenty strong. I haven't really stress tested it that hard, but I when I set it up I cranked down the screw pretty tightly and the motor easily pulls the filament through my pinched fingers. Unlike the original MK7 system with the plunger and washer, I haven't had any stuck filament where the gear thing ends up stripping the filament. Also it's a lot easier to feed new filament (you don't have to cut it at an angle and jam it really hard into the hole).
comments.author: brianblanton

comments.text: I think you're asking about the specs for the bearing? I just googled for a "623 bearing" based on the info from the original design.

description.text:
Hi,

This is an open bumper case for the Raspberry Pi which can be used for a single Pi or multiple.

There are 3 STL files - Top, Middle and Bottom.

Based on what stack you want you will need to print multiple 'Middle' sections. The stacks will lock in with the Pi screw holes to hold the Pi in place and fans can be attached above the pi or to the rear based on airflow / compact needs. If the fan is mounted to the top, there is still spacing to support a heatsink.

This case also provides support to connect a 30mm Pi Fan (https://www.amazon.co.uk/Camac-Brushless-Cooling-Screws-Raspberry/dp/B015W2KRCQ/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1489184536&sr=8-1&keywords=pi+fan)

author: AlanC88

description.text:
OpenSCAD trapezohedra tiles with holes for magnets. Trigonal trapezohedron (a cube), tetragonal trapezohedron, and pentagonal trapezohedron.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trapezohedron

Trigonal (cube): Print 2x3 = 6 faces
Tetragonal: Print 2x4 = 8 faces
Pentagonal: Print 2x5 = 10 faces

Use 4 disc magnets per tile (axially magnetized). Use superglue to secure them in the tiles.

See the User Defined Variables section of the OpenSCAD script for the parameters you may want to change (magnet holes and overall size of tile, total 4 parameters). Or just use the pre-built STL file (designed for 6mm diameter magnets, 1.5-2mm in depth, leaving a little extra room due to typical 3d printer tolerance issues).

Not familiar with OpenSCAD? It is easy to obtain and use! Download it here: http://www.openscad.org. After installation, open up the OpenSCAD file for this thing and hit F6 to render (or use the menu options up top). File->Export as STL and take it to your slicer!

These are also on github: https://github.com/eshira/polyhedra

A quick remix for Proto3000's snap buckle, isolated to just the male prongs, since they're inevitably the ones that break.
I tweaked the dimensions in order to create a custom replacement for my dad's "Mad Bomber" ushanka, first in orange ABS to prototype, and then in black ABS for the final part.

If building a buckle half for yourself:
-Don't use PLA. It's brittle, and work-hardening will break the prongs. ABS at 50% infill works great.
-Do use supports.
-Use a decent infill.
-Use Cura or your printing app to stretch/squash/shrink/embiggen the buckle to match your part. (i.e. turn off scale-lock and scale each dimension independently).
-Use medium-grit sandpaper and a knife for fine finishing post-print if it doesn't quite fit.

description.text:
A replica of the 7.62 x 25 mm Tokarev pistol cartridge (used in the pistol of the same name), which is nearly identical to the older 7.63/.30 Mauser cartridge used in the famous "broomhandle" C96 Mauser pistol (a.k.a. Han Solo's DL-44 blaster) of 1896.

Dimensions were taken from the Lyman's Reloading Manual, 49th edition, and the model built in FreeCAD. The completed ABS "snap cap" (inert replica used to test-fire a gun without leaving the chamber empty) was tested in a Romanian TTC pistol.

As this is a digital copy of a design that's 124 years old, it's entirely in the public domain.

description.text:
UPDATE: Somehow the files I originally uploaded were not aligned correctly for printing. I have corrected the orientation of the files and replaced the original STL files. Hopefullyv these will print better.

I started building this pretty accurate phaser design using Corma's base files. When I started printing, I discovered there were a number of shortcomings in the design. Some parts were not well structured for FDM printing and others were not the correct scale for the finished phaser. I also eliminated some complexity in the design.

You need to print one of each part in the files list EXCEPT the Type 2 main body parts. You can either print the left and right sides separately or there is also a file with them together.

The Type 1 phaser body is held together using 4 - M3x6mm cap screws. I ground the front pair of screws down with a grinder so the head of the cap screw fit flush with the body. I used cap screws because I plan to add a blinking LED and coin style battery in the future.

The Type 2 trigger assembly consists of a ball point pen spring, cut in half, a M3x15mm cap screw, a 3mm length of 4mmODx3mmID PTFE tube and two M3 flat washers. The spring fits in the large hole of the trigger button and is held in by the two washers and cap screw. When assembling, press fit the assembly into one half of the Type 2 Main Body with a washer on the outside and the other on the inside of the body. This will allow for a spring operated switch to be mounted inside the body to activate any electronics you want to add. I glued the body halves together.

Bentonite is best known for its uses in oil, gas and water well drilling, environmental and civil engineering applications, clumping cat litter, foundry sand and is known as a ÃÂ¢ÃÂÃÂmineral with a thousand usesÃÂ¢ÃÂÃÂ. It is used in the construction of dams, canals, reservoirs, landfills and as a sealing material in the construction and rehabilitation of dikes and levees.  bentonite expands when wet, absorbing as much as several times its dry mass in water.  
Because of its excellent colloidal properties, it is often used in drilling mud for oil and gas wells and boreholes for geotechnical and environmental investigations.  The property of swelling also makes bentonite useful as a sealant, since it provides a self-sealing, low permeability barrier. It is used to line the base of landfills for example.

title: QAV210 Lisam LS-210 VTX antenna mount

description.text:
Angled SMA or RP-SMA bracket for mounting the Vtx antenna out the back of the quad.
For use with a pigtail (also called antenna extension cable).
The adapter slides over the spacers, and can optionally be fixed in place with a bit of hot glue.

I made this by modifying a similar adapter for the Hive210, making it wider to support the 3cm width between the spacers on the QAV210 frame, and made the opening where the SMA connector is mounted a bit wider, making it easier to install the connector (in the original part it was a bit narrow).

New version: Added versions that cover the entire height of the spacer, so it's no longer required to lock it with glue. There's a choice out of a centered one, one that sits at the bottom, and one that goes at the top.

title: Stormtrooper ANH modernised.
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I Wanted an accurate and symmetric helmet with nice sharp corners, that could be printed without supports. This is meant to be wearable.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3mm

Infill:

25

Notes:

printed with brims at .3mm layer height in PLA. Needs good bed adhesion. these are big pieces that lean quite a lot. There have been a few external problems, but there is supposed to be a great deal of post print work to do in order to get this piece to completion. had some print problems with the some warping of the larger pieces. Nothing that cant be fixed with epoxy filler and sanding.
friction welding parts together. Filling using epoxy filler and sanding to remove model facets. welded pieces seem strong and most work will be to sand and repeat on the filler surface.

Lots of remodelling from files from various sources. using 3ds max. I built a whole set of smoothing groups and mesh smoothed everything with these to tessellate the surface but still maintain the sharp corners. basically just extruded the inside and relaxed all the faces to get an internal surface that would support the rest of the structure. Sliced the whole thing into radial sections so to further allow support free printing.

comments.text: i`m more a modeler than a printer,  but i would say that must be something to do with the way your slicing it, and maybe your printer.  the prints i did were done on an anet a8 with a .4mm nozzle and a .25mm layer height.  i used cura 1.4 to slice everything for my own gcode.  cura doesnt do any smoothing so all the polygon facets are printed,  rather than the smooth surface that is seen in the blue preview images shown here.  the smoothing information is in the obj files i supplied. It is then possible that newer versions or different slicers will utilize it to get smoother curves.  i did do some testing but that was a while back and ultimately i went for my tried and tested settings in the old version of cura, that worked well for me.  but it has cost me a lot of time sanding and filling since then.

author: Bartlby76

description.text: This is a .22 blank conversion for the Strawberry and Fallout Flashbangs

Happy New Year too all!!  
If you have ever gotten tired of holding a flashlight while printing to see the first layer then this is the thing for you!  
Brief how to on using LED flashlights to make printer lights.

This is what I did. I bought a bunch of the small 3 AAA cell LED flashlights.
Tested them for current draw and the one I liked the most was the Utilitech 65 Lumens unit.
I like this unit because it is only approximately 300ma at 3.3 volts. Also it has just one LED.
The 100 Lumens one was ok, it was approximately 350ma at 3.3 volts. I got these flashlights at Lowe's here in the US for about $3 each. But the bottom line is any of the 3 AAA cell LED flashlights will work. Just check the current on them and make sure that your power supply has the current to spare. THESE HAVE TO HAVE A 3.3 VOLT REGULATOR!! DO NOT USE 12 VOLTS ON THEM WITHOUT A REGULATOR! I'm not going into the wiring too much you guys can figure that out, it is just some LEDs. Just remember plus to plus and negative to negative. Again you will have to have a 3.3 volt regulator. The one I used is from
Digi-Key PN 945-1394-5-ND
Manufacture: Recom Power, PN is R-78C3.3-1.0
It is a step down converter so it is real simple to use. No capacitors or heat sink. 12 volts in on one side and ground in the middle and 3.3 volts out the other pin and that is it. But there is a price to pay for being so simple to use, the thing costs $9 US. I think it is worth it not to have to deal with heat sinks and added parts. I use them a lot in all my embed processor projects. The hardware is just some M3 cap screws, nuts and washers.
I printed with 3 perimeter loops with a layer height of .2mm and support.
As you can see from the photos I just took apart the flashlights and cut them off and mounted them to the printed bases using some #2 sheet metal screws. And that's it, good luck! And as they say in the movies keep moving forward! I have included the Solidworks and 203 STEP files in the ZIP file for anyone that would like to modify it.

description.text:
Here are the rest of the series OpenLock adapters with a Wood pattern. The point of these is the twists and changes that can occur on a wood floor. One side matches to common 1x tiles, S, SA and SB and the other corresponding sides match the 1x tiles NA, SD?, SC.
An advantage, taking 2 S-NA NS tiles, matching the S sides makes an EA style tile (Picture #1).
Matching the NA sides make a combination E/EA tile "adapter" (Picture #2).

The NS/EW designation (for the OCD in me) is the direction of the floor boards when the common spaced side is on the East side. (I'll follow up with some pictures).
SB-SC combines to make a standard RB tile (Picture #3) while switching sides will make an R adapter (Picture #4).

title: Vertical Spool Holder with optional Bearing Filament Guide

description.text:
This is a simpler version of the Makerbot Filament Spool that is only set up for mounting vertically on top of the makerbot. This version doesn't try to grip the whole spool - it's just long enough to hold the spool securely.
Optionally I've added a ball bearing filament guide, mainly because I had an extra 623 bearing from making my "Even more minimal MK7 extruder bearing filament feeder"
There's also a non-bearing version of the guide which I haven't tried, but should work totally fine.
Net-net is the silky smoothest filament feeding system in the Thingiverse ;)

For the spool holder, just print and attach to the top right (or left) corner of your Makerbot using 4 M3 screws and nuts.
For the optional filament guide: remove the thin "support" cylinder where the 623 bearing goes and also remove the support material in the arch. Attach bearing with an M3 screw. Attach the filament guide to the UNDERSIDE of the top lip of the makerbot (see pics)
For the non-bearing version, just print and attach as above!
I printed these with 50% infill for strength

comments.text: I had an existing spool holder design, so I only printed the filament guide (without bearing). It works great! I just finished a two-hour print without having to touch the filament at all, which is a personal first!

Chassis for mini-sumo robot designed for use with Pololu components.

Details and updates: https://forum.pololu.com/t/new-mini-sumo-project/12072

Specifications:

Overall dimensions: W: 96mm, L: 95mm, H: 49mm (3.78" x 3.71" x 1.93" approx) including cover
Weight: 215 g (chassis, cover and components without added weights), up to ~375g with added weights.
Motors*: 2 x 75:1 Micro Metal Gearmotor HPCB 6V or 2 x 50:1 Micro Metal Gearmotor HPCB 6V with Pololu Micro Metal Gearmotor Brackets
Wheels: 2 x Solarbotics RW2 Wheel (external set screw)
Battery: 2S Li-Po 800 mAh (55 mm x 31 mm x 17 mm max size)
Microcontroller: A-Star 32U4 Robot Controller LV with Raspberry Pi Bridge (SMT Components Only)
Sensors: 2 x Sharp GP2Y0A60SZLF Analog Distance Sensor, 2 x QTR-1RC Reflectance Sensors and 1 x MinIMU-9 v5 Inertial Measurement Unit.

Build notes:

Holes in the 3D model are smaller than finished size. Print the model as-is and finish the holes after printing as per instructions below:

  • Blade holes: Finish with 1/8" drill. Use #4-40 x 5/16" screws and nuts.
  • Sharp sensor carrier holes: Finish minor diameter with 3/32" drill. Tap #4-40 screws directly in chassis.
  • Motor bracket holes: Finish with 3/32" drill. Use #2-56 x 7/16" screws and nuts (provided with the brackets).
  • IMU and A-Star robot controller holes: Finish minor diameter with 1/16" drill. Tap #2-56 x 1/4" screws directly in chassis (making a very shallow hole with a 5/64" drill helps the screw thread to engage in the plastic). Use 1/4" standoffs on top of the A-Star robot controller, these will serve to mount the cover.
  • QTR sensors holes need no additional finishing. Use #2-56 x 1/4" screws and nuts.
  • Cover mounting holes: Finish with 3/32" drill. Use #2-56 x 1/4" screws.
  • Cover weight mounting holes: Finish with 1/8" drill as needed. Use #4 x 1/2" screws and nuts to hold the weights.

For the blade, I used a stainless steel ruler similar to the type with cork backing except mine has a synthetic foam backing instead. I used scotchbrite to erase the ruler graduation markings.

The weights mounted in the cover are made from 1/2" x 1/8" mild steel bar. Adjust the number and position of the weights to achieve the desired weight and weight distribution between the wheels and the blade.

author: juanruiz

description.text:
After getting frustrated trying to get my keyhole router bit to work reliably, (really cheap one), I decided to try something else.

I designed this so it can be used on the edge of a 3/4" thick board to mount to a screw in a wall.

It will snugly fit into a 5/8" hole that's 1/2" deep. Definitely recommend using a forestner bit to drill the hole.

The screws will need to have a head no wider than 1/4" and a shank of about 1/8".

I applied a 5 minute epoxy to the hole then pressed in the plug. So far they're working great! I haven't tested how much weight these will support, but seem to be pretty sturdy as long as they're glued in securely.

Another thing that's nice about this over a keyhole router bit is that these should be more secure in the edge of a piece of plywood.

author: juanruiz

description.text:
This project is really an extension of my Forward Offset Pan & Tilt and my recent Lightweight Pan and Tilt. The Lightweight P&T uses printed gears and this unit uses "Store Bought" Acetyl gears which (for me) work much more smoothly. Built to my published specs, it will turn 390 degrees and tilt 110 degrees total. It is designed around the Turnigy™ TGY-R5180MG 180 Degree Metal Gear Analog Servo and a pair of 32 pitch Acetyl gears from ServoCity. It is a bit more robust and with the new gears much smoother. It will cover the entire 390 degree sweep with standard servo output of 1000µs to 2000µs and centers very well.

For more information and detailed build instructions please see my Wiki build article for this project:

http://www.itsqv.com/QVM/index.php?title=390_Degree_Geared_Pan_and_Tilt

Designed to be printed with soft PLA. 20% infill with 3,3,0,0 layers. Slowed the print when
finishing the hinges. Takes about 40 minutes to print both sides. A hot water bath will let it flatten out.

This material seemed to have a high adhesive quality. I started with a clean glass bed, put on a coat of auto wax and scrapped the excess off with a razor blade. Used HD hair spray on top of the wax for a nice clean print with easy release. This worked for a large flat print.

Takes two holders to make the build. I heated and straighten regular PLA for hinge pins. Will also print with TPU.

V2. Designed to be printed with TPU. Soft PLA is not soft enough for the hinge. Hinge printed @ 100% .2 layer, reduced speed for the last part. Ends may try and lift up during print. They may curl after print. Extra time spent on hinge cleanup will help the assembly process. 2x=32+min.

Side printed @ 30% 4.5.0.0 @ 100% speed. 2x=38min approx.

Used [email protected] hinge to side attachment. This build seems to adhere to the cup better.

description.text:
This is my remix of the excellent Mantis Gripper. My goal was to automate the tedious task of testing cash dispensers at work using scrap and off the shelf parts. Video here: https://youtu.be/ED8kZkMuPWg. I needed a larger flat gripping area than the original Gripper, so I modified both the large and small grippers. I used everything else from the original Mantis. I added screw-on sensor brackets to the ends of the two grippers to house an infrared emitter/sensor combo. A stand was designed so I could attach the gripper to a motorized slide base. There are various motor mounts, sensor mounts, belt grips and the like that I designed. You can them use as-is or customize them using the 123D design files in the ZIP file.

The gripper itself is controlled by an Arduino and the moving slide it's mounted on is run by an Adafruit Motor Shield. The function of the assembly is to sense when bills are presented into the open gripper. It closes the gripper, moves the gripper rearward on a track and then opens the gripper to drop the bills into a bin below. A running bill counter is incremented, and It then moves forward till it hits the limit switch to wait for more bills. Over and over again. This takes the place of a tech having to sit and do this for 30 minutes at a time.

EDIT 6/2/17 The first grabber was so well received that the techs commissioned another one. I printed it entirely in "Watermelon" PETG from MakerGeeks. See pic #5.
The rubber is holding up well; no sign of wear at all and we're using it daily.

I used a Hitec HS-645MG Servo from Servocity for the grabber, and it's lived up to it's billing as "durable high torque servo". It's a bit spendy, but I've had no issues at all running all day long.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Printrbot Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2064

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I printed all components with PETG for its durability and overall ease of printing.

I knew that the screws in the pulley stand needed to be adjusted occasionally to tension the drive belt, so I used brass screw inserts. Grainger.com # 4ZU26 7mm insert. I pushed them into the holes of the stand using a soldering iron. Worked perfectly.
I used Autodesk's 123D Design to modify the original gripper files and to design the other odds and ends required.

description.text:
This is my Y-Axis belt tensioner for the Creality CR-10 3D printer. It replaces the 3D printed idler that holds the Y-axis in place on the machine.

I took inspiration from other belt tensioners on thingiverse, namely idig3d's "Tronxy X3 x-belt tensioner" (Thing:2020468). The knob used here is idig3d's knob, not mine.

You will need one M5x25 bolt and a match nut (hex head is recommended for the screw)

UPDATE 03/13/17: Re-uploaded the stl's in "ready to print" orientation.
UPDATE 03/28/17: Uploaded both STEP and Fusion360 achrive files for those who wish to build off this design.

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

35%

Notes:

I used 35% infill but I'm sure lower would work as well.

Everything should be printed in it's default orientation. The bracket can be done without supports if you're confident in your printers bridging ability. Otherwise, just use supports.

In order to assemble this, you have to remove the existing 3D printed idler and remove the T nuts that held it in place. This design does not use the T nuts so you can save them for something else.

Remove the belt from the pulley on the other end of Y-axis so that you have more slack to work with.

Push the M5 bolt all the way into the puller so that the hex head rests inside the cutout for it and the threads protrude out the back of it. You may have to lightly tap the M5 into it's place using a hammer and a screwdriver.

Use the existing M4 bolt to put the lock the idler wheel and belt in place inside the puller. Then slip the bracket's T's into the 2040's T slots with the puller in its place inside the bracket.

Push the M5 nut into the slot made for it in idig3d's knob.

Put the belt back onto the pulley at the Y-axis motor.

Lastly, slip the endcap onto the back of the bracket and screw the knob into the M5 bolt.

remixed_from.title: Mean Well SP-320 Power Supply Cover for Prusa i3

title: Mean Well SE-600 Power Supply Cover

description.text:
Power supply cover for the Meanwell SE-600 (http://www.meanwell.com/productPdf.aspx?i=469) for printers that need moar power.

Has a mount for a 15A inlet with an integrated switch: https://www.digikey.com/product-detail/en/1-1609112-2/CCM1916-ND/2292077. If you are using a different one you'll need to adjust the powerSocket() module. The cover was designed to be as shallow as possible, I would recommend using high strand count 12-14 awg wire (silicone jacket) for wiring the inlet to the psu -- the psu terminal block is positioned awkwardly so the wires need to flex a bit or it's a pain to assemble.

Vents give adequate airflow and it seems to baffle the fan a bit. DC side has a wide slot for running wires out , a zip tie through the vents works as a makeshift strain relief. A future revision may feature powerpole or another high current connector mount, depending on when I get the itch to make my printer wiring cleaner.

Original openscad was designed for a PSU with terminals on only one side so it's a bit wonky to generate the dc and ac side: set COVER_DEPTH appropriately, and then call either dc_cover() or ac_cover(). I might fix that one day.

Note: dc side in the picture doesn't fit on fully, I have corrected the depth in the stl so there shouldn't be any problem but I haven't had a reason to reprint mine yet.

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Designed to be printed with a 0.5mm nozzle and two walls -- sides of the case will print only as walls making the print time reasonable. If you have a different nozzle size or want to use more walls, customize the WALL (in mm) variable.

Printed in PETG @ 2mm wall, it's a bit flexible unattached but plenty strong and stiff once mounted. PLA probably would work as well, but I suspect ABS would warp itself apart with the tall thin walls.

description.text:
This is a landing gear for the Bebop 2. using the stock mounting screws. Use 1/16 in shock cord or light extension springs to give about a 2 inch lift for deep grass and softer landings. Use small wood screws to mount the legs to the extensions. Screws hold legs in place and act as pivot point. video of action : https://youtu.be/3bs2jehNKvs
Import legs in mm, gear plates in inches

50% or more

Notes:

Shells thick for rigidity. print 4 legs and 2 each of the gear plates. print legs laying horizontal similar to the picture of the leg, with the round peg to the print bed, and supports along the long axis.

designed to replace stock bebop 2 landing gear with stock mounting screws.

remove stock landing gears, assemble leg on gears, use shock cord or small light weight extension springs to as needed to get even leg positions.

A very simple, yet effective speaker box. Can be printed as a single or twin box.

Can easily be upscaled to fit any speaker

Duinotech

No

Supports:

No

The SD Card holder on the 101Hero is only held by the pin connector so it could get damaged, pins bent, etc. So I created a support that provide the top end with the same level of support the connector does on the bottom, so the holder can be pressed against the control box and remain parallel without bending. I also made a cover, based on an idea I saw in the 101Hero forum, that covers pins that are exposed and that you can feel a small electrical current from if touched while the printer is powered up.They are both friction fit and possibly a bit loose based on the printed materials. I printed these on the 101hero, with PLA, 205 C, .2mm layers, 20% fill.

title: Black Widow Z-Axis G2T Belt Relocation
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Black Widow Z-Axis G2T Belt Relocation

This Mod was designed to increase the Height of the Black Widow Printer by incorporating printed corner blocks to change the location of the z axis belt from below the top cross beam to above the top cross beam. I have included a few add on’s that are not needed for the mod but do make the printer look better and protects the new belt location.
Unfortunately, this mod does require some extra screws and t-nuts. Listed below are parts that are recommended to purchase or obtain before beginning.

1 M4 x 8mm Hex Cap Screws QTY=70 ( Can be bought on Amazon or Ebay or any hardware source that supplies metric screws)

2 M4 drop in T-Nuts QTY=70 ( Can be bought on Amazon or Ebay or any hardware source that supplies metric screws)

3 M5 x 30 Hex Flat Head Screws QTY=16 ( Can be bought on Amazon or Ebay or any hardware source that supplies metric screws) Used with Top and Bottom Z-Axis Caps

4 M3 x 45mm Hex Cap Screws QTY=4 ( Can be bought on Amazon or Ebay or any hardware source that supplies metric screws) Mine were obtained from OpenBuilds Parts Store. Used with z-Axis Motor Mount.

5 8mm ID Lock Collar with grub screw QTY=2 Purchased from Open Builds Parts Store.

Optional Parts: While the printed Upper top cap has a location for a 16OD x 8mmID bearing it can be used or left off and just use the existing 4 that came with the Black Widow.

Parts you need to Print:
SWD_Bottom_Plate Qty=2
Install at bottom of each Z-Axis C-Channel
(Each=Uses 8-M4 Screws & T-nuts Also Uses 4-M5x30 hex Flat Head Screw)

SWD_Top_Plate_Frame_Mount Qty=2
Install at top of each Z-Axis C-Channel
(Each=Uses 1-M5 x 30mm Hex Flat Head Screws)

SWD_Top_Plate_Frame_Mount Cover Qty=2
Install at the top of the Top Plate Frame Mount
(Each=Uses 3-M5 x 30mm Hex Flat Head Screws)

SWD_Center_Base_Corner QTY=4
Install in the 4 corners where the Y Axis and X Axis Join
(Each=Uses 2-M4 Screws & T-nuts)

SWD_Leg_Base Qty=8
Install 2 on each section of the Y/X legs
(Each=Uses 2-M4 Screws & T-nuts)

SWD_Corner_Brace_Large Qty=8
Install 2 per each corner of the Z-Axis Frame
(Each=Uses 2-M4 Screws & T-nuts)

SWD_z-AXIS_MOTOR_MOUNT Qty=1
Install using existing Z-axis Mounting Plate
(Uses 4-M3 x 45mm Screws)

Please note all the frame brackets are designed to overlap the existing BW metal L-Brackets. They are used as a secondary lock down for the existing brackets.

Secondary Add-Ons:
Belt Shield Covers-Snap fit.
SWD_Top_Belt_Shield_Center Qty=1
SWD_Top_Belt_Shield_Left Qty=1
SWD_Top_Belt_Shield_Motor Qty=1

Spool Holder and Spool Rods

SWD_Spool_Holder_Tower Qty=2
(Each=Uses 2-M4 Screws & T-nuts)

SWD_Spool_Holder_Rod101 Qty=1

SWD_Spool_Holder_Rod121 Qty=1

Please note I distribute these freely but request that you do not Sell or Profit from these files as they were created from scratch by me. Also I ask that if you make and appreciate these files for your Black Widow Printer that you post your make as I would love to see what others have done with their machines.

Additional Notes:
To make this mod fully functional 3 additional things are required.
1 BL-Touch Leveling Sensor installed.
With the BL Touch installed you can remove the springs from your bed screws and replace with m-3 lock nuts. By doing so you can reduce the height of your heated bed to ½” or 13mm above the y axis gantry. This will gain 15mm of z height.

2 http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1777681 Install the horizontal drag chain Mod from the thingiverse link.
This will gain 18mm Z-Height.

(note the top brackets move the top brace rail up 17mm and moving the GT2 Belt above the top Brace gains an additional 20mm. Total change in Height from stock-17+20+18+15=70mm)

3 reflash firmware to adjust total z-height from existing setting to 320mm (Note as you level your bed after level you can set this higher and manually move your z up until it maxes out by stopping on the corner blocks. At that point revise and adjust your max z-height to 2mm less than where your upper most z stopped.)

Be Warned first I am publishing this in good faith that those that download this have the skills to install and assemble this mod. I take no responsibility if your machine is damaged and is solicited as a use at your own risk statement.

Update 2-May-2017 The top cap does not align well with the rest of the z-axis lead screw. Please do not use a 3rd bearing in the top cap let the top of the lead screw turn free without a bearing. I will update this soon but currently the easy fix is to not use a bearing and just use the cap to support the belt shield.

As a Final Note Good Luck and hope the build goes well for you.
If you like this mod please "LIKE" as this puts it close to the top of the search to make it easier for your friends to find.
Sincerely, Shadowweaver2067
AKA Anthony Harmon

Printer:

Black Widow

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Cooling Fan=Yes 100%
Feed=55mm P/S

This was designed after I assembled my Black Widow Printer From TEVO. Upon realizing that the combination of the stock drag chain and the GT2 belts below the Top Brace hogged up about 50mm of z height I looked at designing an alternative to mostly use existing parts to raise the Z lead screw and move the GT2 Belt above the top cross piece.

comments.text: My bearing are a bit loose in the slots like the stock aluminum parts where I had to put a paper sheet to keep them tight as per the CG. Should I reprint everything at 99-98 scale? My calibration 20mm cube comes out at +/- 0.09mm off
comments.author: iggut

comments.text: If your printer is out of calibration for size you will have to adjust the parts in your slicer to accomodate for the variance. That is something I cannot control for you. Hope that helps.
comments.author: iggut

comments.text: seems too well calibrated lol 0.09mm tolerance seems like near perfect, but I guess I can do better :D
comments.author: ShadowWeaver2067

comments.text: There are several factors that could be causing it to be loose or tight...one is extrusion multiplier which can cause over and under extrusion when this happens the dimensional difference can vary widely depending on the variance in your filament diameter and how fast your extruder is producing material. Typically I tend to play with those first before actually scaling a part in the slicer. For instance right now my filament is an avg of 1.74mm but my extrusion multiplier is .90 because I have a 10% variance in my filament since it can vary from 1.69 to 1.79. Also remember 9x out of 10 the first layer can be "larger" than the rest making the part seem like its out of scale that most of the time is based on the initial layer squish. Hope that helps.
comments.author: iggut

comments.text: I think you are right about my calibration. I did not listen and reprinted with 98% after measuring the bearing hole. The bearing snap in like the hole is made for them, but now the part is 0.3-0.4 mm to narrow to fit and deform the parts slightly. I will try to force them on this week, but probably a re-calibration and reprint lol.

customized with 3D Slash!

Inspired by an old yo-yo, it's an all printable (except the string) bearing style yo-yo. It can be assembled with the printable M5-0.8 hex head bolt and nut, real versions of the same type, or any combination of them. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OrdY62d68W8

Print Settings (printed on a UM2; PLA; 50C bed):
-As fast as your printer will print on the yo-yo halves; 80% Infill.
-Print the core as slow and as cold as you can at 100 micron to prevent curling; it's a hard print, if it doesn't come out well remember it's the center that really matters; 100% Infill.
-Bolt and nut 40 mm/s 190C at 100 micron; 100% Infill. *Printing on a non-heated blue tape bed is preferred as it will create very slightly rounded bottoms on the yo-yo halves meaning less string friction potential. Stuff to know: Twist the two halves together and test action incrementally to get the perfect fit. Use a lock nut if going with the real version, the printable version has its threads stop a bit before the end preventing the bolt from turning any more. Don't turn the bolt too hard you will crack the nut as in the image above, it's pretty hard to do. Use petroleum jelly as a lubricator between the core and bolt interface. If using a real bolt, sand the threads down a bit by twisting the bolt through some sand paper; this will prevent the threads from potentially cutting into the plastic. For a permanent device, glue a real lock nut and bolt into their respective cutouts. It's not recommended to glue the plastic bolt into place as it will break if the yo-yo hits a hard surface at high velocity.

title: Nintendo Switch Cartridge Holder for Dock / Stand - 6 slot
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a dock mounted 6 slot cartridge holder for the Nintendo Switch which is locked into place by the door on the back of the original Switch dock - since the door makes a great snap in mounting point.

Should print without any support in the default file orientation, I don't think it would print well rotated from the default orientation without a lot of post processing. Please note, this holder needs to sit on the right of the switch dock, aligning the semi circular cut outs on the print with the protruding tabs on the inside of the Switch dock door.

Let me know in comments how you go with the fit, my printer does pretty close to scale - maybe a tad under. Had some mild oozing issues inside the cart slots which made some of the slots a little tight for me, but if your printer is dialed in better than mine it should be fine - or it can probably be fixed with a hobby knife.

For now a small six slot, future plans are a longer version running most of the length of the switch, possibly 2/3 tiered to show of a large collection of carts.

Disclaimer: please use at your own risk - I take no responsibility for this thing scratching your switch dock, setting your house of fire, or your kids/pets turning this into an easy access all you can eat Switch cartridge buffet.

*Update (26/07/2017): Version 3, slimmed down the slots so carts can less easily fall sideways. Still a little loose as I didn't want the carts to be scratched. Includes V2 changes.

*Update (14/03/2017): Version 2 added a little more room for airflow if that is a major concern - although between the HDMI cutout on the dock and the gaps to the side of the holder it shouldn't be.

Printer:

Fabrikator Mini

No

description.text:
Based on Medelis' excellent http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2017207. About 36 inches tall. Used about 800m of filament (2 rolls), infill anywhere between 2-10% on a DaVinci 1.0.

The trick I used in Simplify3D was for each object to have 3 processes by Z height (lower 3mm infill 10%, middle 2-4%, upper 3mm 10%) such that the upper and lower plates would have good support for gluing. This saved a lot of filament and time plus reduced file size so the Davinci would not crash, but the default 3 perimeters would show occasional gaps on 45 degree slopes vs the 4 perimeters that worked a lot better.

Most importantly, when using sparse infill use 4 or more perimeters to prevent gaps in outer skin. Glue sections with Home Depot ABS glue for ABS pipes from Plumbing section.

I plan to use a 3D pen to fill the section where the layers split, sand the joins, acetone smooth, then primer then paint dark gold color.

description.text:
PRINT WITH NO SUPPORT (There is a small bit of built in support that will remove easily.)

This is one 3D print, no need to assemble anything. The joy stick prints in place and rotates straight off the print bed. It does not "return to center" like a real joy stick, but makes a great fidget toy. It has a small hole in one corner so you can hook it to a backpack, bag, coat zipper, or keyring.

Here is a link to a Tinkercad Tutorial if you want to make your own: https://youtu.be/3UJ5uBTbivs

Here's a (not very exciting) video showing removing the support material off the print bed: https://youtu.be/3VPwNkBYmb8

Creator Pro

Notes:

100% infill is easiest. There is a lot of empty space in this print, so it doesn't use as much plastic as you might think. If you really don't want to do 100% infill, set a couple process settings with your slicer so that the area below and above the joy stick handle is 100% or it can break off with vigorous rotations.
Rotate the joy stick and the built in support should fall out of the bottom. You can also use needle-nosed pliers to pull it out.
In Tinkercad: tutorial above

Joysticks are popular with everyone, but especially kids, so I decided to do a tutorial on how to make a basic 3d printable joystick.  Once a student gets the idea of it, they can improve on the design or incorporate it into other projects.

Make sure students have Tinkercad accounts.
Watch tutorial video.
Create their own version following tips given in tutorial.

Computer with internet access
Tinkercad account
3D printer & filament

• tinkercad
  • joystick
  • ball & socket
1-2 hours

Make sure students have Tinkercad accounts and access to YouTube instructional video.
Make sure 3D printer is working and loaded with filament!

comments.text: As far as measuring real life items for holsters and such, trial and error. Find as much info as you can online about an items dimentions or CAD drawings. Other than that, a set of calipers and some guess work, trial and error.
comments.author: MrPopo

comments.text: That particular printer is rather small 120mm. Most printers a 200mm cube build space, which my Prusa i3 has. If your looking to print smaller moddels, that selection would work for you. As far as software, I use Cura. You import a model of your choice into Cura and it converts it into "slices" that the printer can understand. Tons of options for slicing. Youtube and some Google research is what got me started. I watched videos that were "3D printing basics", explaing how to use Cura as well as actual models being printed.

description.text:
Warning: Not calibrated for celestial navigation. Use at your own risk.

https://youtu.be/jIwPm9D4boM

Makes use of the following projects:
Earth: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:86681
Moon: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:755855

Print one of each file at the highest resolution you can tolerate. No supports needed.
Paint prior to assembly. I used metallic acrylic paints. I used modelling glue to assemble the Earth and Moon, and to glue parts to the metal pegs.

The metal pegs are simply nails with the sharp ends ground down. They measure 2.53mm by my digital calipers.

The musicbox mechanism is a Sankyo 18-note. Available widely, just Google it. Most popular songs from the early to mid 20th century are available. Why did I use "Fiddle on the Roof"? It was the most spacey sounding song that came in an 8-pack of mechanisms for $15.

You'll need the optional extension shaft for your Sankyo music box. Available here for $0.95: http://www.whittemoredurgin.com/7177-smoothshaft

You will need eight 10mm M3 bolts to hold the musicbox mechanism to the base and the rest of the musicbox together. You will need one 5mm M3 bolt to tighten the Earth's gear to the extension shaft.

And yes, I realize the earth is rotating the wrong way. Take it up with Sankyo.

comments.text: Two questions:
comments.author: frestepi

comments.text: Your first question likely refers to the sideways hole in the tallest of the small gears. This hole is for an M3 screw to tighten the gear against the rotating metal rod coming out of the music box. Without this, the gear would rotate freely on the rod.

description.text: The Progressive Hard Rock / Metal Band Logo Designed in 123Design.

Small side project I decided to embark on. Simple accessories for Lightsaber builders to print themselves (or order). Most of this is stuff you can get elsewhere, and with better aesthetics. These are just basic things, none of which takes a whole lot filament and should all be dirt cheap.

Blade plug caps:
Just simple caps to place on excess tube from cut-down Lightsaber blades. Available for both 1" and 7/8" blades.

Kill keys for recharge ports:
-No. 1 has a tab for external or in-hilt recharge ports (or if you got a lot of space inside hilt).
-No. 2 is 14mm tall. Sticks out of a recharge port just enough to use fingers.
-No. 3 is 12mm tall. Sticks out of a recharge port, might need pliers to pull out.

Switchcraft Recharge Port adapters for 12mm holes. All need adhesive to secure to hole/hilt:
-Nut version - Just place the RCP through the adapter piece, and secure on with the supplied nut.
-Flush version - Deeper version where the RCP sits flush with the adapter and hilt, slides right in, but need adhesive to secure to adapter.
-Screw version - This DOES NOT have threading. This is meant for those who can tap in their own threads, and secure the RCP to the adapter by screwing it in.

The recharge port adapters was a solution I came up with for a problem that came to my attention from other Saber builders for working on Saberforge hilts (or any other hilt that comes with 12mm holes as a standard). A lot of people don't like using the cheap recharge ports, and really prefer the Switchcraft one. Even though the cheaper ones fit the 12mm holes better, they are less reliable and ruin the aesthetic (i.e., they are ugly, haha). These adapters will allow them to use the Switchcraft ones.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/kEsNXXpOigq

title: Armattan Chameleon Rear VTX holder support

description.text:
The Armattan Chameleon rear VTX hold can break if you have a crash on the rear. This happened to me. I created this little something to help give an undamaged one more chance of surviving a crash and use my broken one but with extra strength until a replacement arrives.

This was designed to fit Eachine TX526 & ET200R, but will most likely fit most others. Take a look at those two VTX to see if yours is similar, if so they should work.

It also includes an angled LED strip mount and space to route wires.

description.text:
I was rebuilding one of my Tippmann 98s and I lost the safety. Since I lend them out to friends, I could not leave it like that (or stomach paying $10 for a replacement).

Luckily I had another gun with the safety button still in and a digital caliper.

The upright print did not go so well, so I printed it sideways with supports.

After printing clean up supports and add to R01 o-rings to either side. If you have a red one you can mark the button as unsafe.
